questions.question_text:
A networking administrator was recently promoted to security administrator in an organization that handles highly sensitive data. The Chief Information Security
Officer (CISO) has just asked for all IT security personnel to review a zero-day vulnerability and exploit for specific application servers to help mitigate the organization's exposure to that risk. Which of the following should the new security administrator review to gain more information? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: The real problem with this question is CompTIA assuming that Network Administration -> Security Administration is a "promotion"...
ACG is the correct answer

Maybe: B. Recent security industry conferences?
"A zero-day vulnerability is a vulnerability in a system or device that has been disclosed but is not yet patched."
https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/definition/zero-day-vulnerability
If the vulnerability is known, it may have been discussed at recent security industry conferences.

Maybe: F. Server's vendor documentation?
This would be true in cases where the server vendor also developed the software. For example: an Oracle DB running on a Solaris box. Or an IBM box running AIX.
I believe C&G are for sure correct answers. Having trouble deciding the last one though.

Maybe: A. CVE database ?
CVE: reference dictionary for publicly known security vulnerabilities and exposures
provides standardized names (identifiers) of vulnerabilities

comments.content: It's a 0-day vuln, so it won't have been assigned a CVE yet.

Sure about that? "Zero-day-vulnerability" only means it has not been patched yet.
Zero-day-vulnerabilities can be publicly known. 
https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/definition/zero-day-vulnerability
CVE is a reference dictionary for publicly known security vulnerabilities and exposures.

Not true. Zero vulnerability only means no patch available, but it may be in CVE database. It may not be the first day or second day, but rest assured that after 3 days will. A patch may not be available for another 2-3 days but there is some info in CVE database.

questions.question_text: A company has decided to replace all the T-1 uplinks at each regional office and move away from using the existing MPLS network. All regional sites will use high- speed connections and VPNs to connect back to the main campus. Which of the following devices would MOST likely be added at each location?

discussion.content: D1960 posting shit without reading the question AGAIN? amazing!!!!

comments.content: The company is moving AWAY from MPLS, which requires special hardware from the ISP. The company wants to use regular high-speed internet with a site-to-site VPN tunnel. This is exactly what you an enterprise router to do.

Concur. Routers would be required at all sites to establish VPN connections across the Internet. CompTIA is really teasing us by putting "Firewall" as an option for this question... likely there will be F/Ws at each site too, but the question only asks for ONE answer.

discussion.content:
According to this, a router is not needed.
Configuring Site-to-site VPN over MPLS 
https://documentation.meraki.com/MX/Site-to-site_VPN/Configuring_Site-to-site_VPN_over_MPLS

choices.A: Run a protocol analyzer to determine what traffic is flowing in and out of the server, and look for ways to alter the data stream that will result in information leakage or a system failure.
choices.B: Send out spear-phishing emails against users who are known to have access to the network-based application, so the red team can go on-site with valid credentials and use the software.
choices.C: Examine the application using a port scanner, then run a vulnerability scanner against open ports looking for known, exploitable weaknesses the application and related services may have.
choices.D: Ask for more details regarding the engagement using social engineering tactics in an attempt to get the organization to disclose more information about the network application to make attacks easier.

questions.question_text: An external red team is brought into an organization to perform a penetration test of a new network-based application. The organization deploying the network application wants the red team to act like remote, external attackers, and instructs the team to use a black-box approach. Which of the following is the BEST methodology for the red team to follow?

discussion.content:
Maybe: D. Ask for more details regarding the engagement using social engineering tactics in an attempt to get the organization to disclose more information about the network application to make attacks easier. 
Social engineering can be a very efficient way to gather data. 
It would make sense to use C and D. I would use C first. But it is easily possible that D would you give you more information.

comments.content: DO NOT MISLEADING PEOPLE AGAIN! IF PEOPLE CONFUSED AND FAILED, YOU HAPPY, RIGHT?
yes, he is a very sad person.... maybe take time to get a wife and a good life instead of publishing misleading responses D1960?
They are on site. I think the second part about acting as if they were remote was there to trick you.

discussion.content: Answer C: However, I wish CompTIA would include some verbiage eluding to the fact that they are doing this "off-site" (per the organization's request). The answer reads to me as if they are inside the organization doing the pen test.
Agree that C is what a red team basically does.
C, basic red team steps

Maybe B?
Protocol analyzers are not very useful unless the company is allowing unencrypted data. Nobody does that. Even hobbyist blogs use https today. Seems to me a social media strategy might make more sense.
a & c are the right answer. they are the only temporary attributes
I'm gonna have to go with A&C here guys.
I would say A&E. Although I would want to swap E with C. But I’ve always read to put legal and human life above all.

comments.content:
Maybe B: Essential information needed to perform data restoration to a known clean state ?
I am not sure that temporary file system and swap space are in volatile memory.
But I would think anything, including what is in volatile memory, would be included in B.

discussion.content:
A. CPU, process state tables, and main memory dumps
C. Temporary file system and swap space 
The issue is the machines were panic powered off--destroying all the volatile memory. 
B/D should be manageable with logs and configuration guides
E is a maybe, but the machines were isolated so presumably you could sign an affidavit that you shut them off and locked them in a closet immediately. That's about as good as it could get in this scenario.
The only thing really lost was the volatile memory information...

A. CPU, process state tables, and main memory dumps

D. Indicators of compromise to determine ransomware encryption

questions.question_text:
First responders, who are part of a core incident response team, have been working to contain an outbreak of ransomware that also led to data loss. In a rush to isolate the three hosts that were calling out to the NAS to encrypt whole directories, the hosts were shut down immediately without investigation and then isolated.
Which of the following were missed? (Choose two.)

choices.A: CPU, process state tables, and main memory dumps
choices.D: Indicators of compromise to determine ransomware encryption
choices.B: Essential information needed to perform data restoration to a known clean state
choices.E: Chain of custody information needed for investigation
choices.C: Temporary file system and swap space

comments.content: Take a look at line: [00:00:25] - that looks like a script.

Cross Site Scripting, involves attakcers discovering and exploiting vulns on website in order to inject malicious code. Attackers take advantage of poor input validation, in this case the filename parameter is not validated.

CSRF is basically when the attacker sends a forged link and it does an unintended action because the user is already authenticated.
Would you mind explaining why it's XSS, not CSRF?

discussion.content: lol what? the answer is XSS.

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B. The key difference between those two attacks is that a CSRF attack requires an authenticated session, while XSS attacks don't. Line 25 indicates a need for authentication.
Definitely XSS, if you’re confused, google examples of each....

comments.content: On review I agree with boblee, XSS not CSRF.

discussion.content:
Probably B
Cross Site Request Forgery, looks like someone is impersonating this webpage and asking people to send usernames and passwords over email. Not a very sophisticated attack, but probably good enough to catch a few phish.
